dr.app.beagle.evomodel.substmodel
Class BaseSubstitutionModel

java.lang.Object
  dr.inference.model.AbstractModel
      dr.app.beagle.evomodel.substmodel.BaseSubstitutionModel
All Implemented Interfaces:
SubstitutionModel, Model, ModelListener, StatisticList, VariableListener, MPISerializable, Identifiable, java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractCodonModel, EmpiricalAminoAcidModel, EmpiricalCodonModel, GeneralSubstitutionModel, GTR, HKY, MutationDeathModel, PCACodonModel, ProductChainSubstitutionModel, TN93
public abstract class BaseSubstitutionModel
extends AbstractModel
implements SubstitutionModel

An abstract base class for substitution models.

Version:
$Id: AbstractSubstitutionModel.java,v 1.41 2005/05/24 20:25:58 rambaut Exp $
Author:
Andrew Rambaut, Marc Suchard, Alexei Drummond

handleVariableChangedEvent

protected void handleVariableChangedEvent(Variable variable,
                                          int index,
                                          Variable.ChangeType type)
Description copied from class: AbstractModel
This method is called whenever a parameter is changed.

It is strongly recommended that the model component sets a "dirty" flag and does no further calculations. Recalculation is typically done when the model component is asked for some information that requires them. This mechanism is 'lazy' so that this method can be safely called multiple times with minimal computational cost.

Specified by:
handleVariableChangedEvent in class AbstractModel

Description copied from class: AbstractModel
Additional state information, outside of the sub-model is stored by this call.

acceptState

protected void acceptState()
Description copied from class: AbstractModel
This call specifies that the current state is accept. Most models will not need to do anything. Sub-models are handled automatically and do not need to be considered in this method.

Specified by:
acceptState in class AbstractModel

checkFrequencies

private void checkFrequencies()
Ensures that frequencies are not smaller than MINFREQ and that two frequencies differ by at least 2*MINFDIFF. This avoids potential problems later when eigenvalues are computed.
